text:
Crime and Punishment

He writes about bad behavior (whom I saw last night for the first time)—but to the widow. I see this as a quick attempt to slander me and create conflict between us. He uses legal terms, which shows his clear intentions and eagerness. He is smart, but being smart isn’t enough to act wisely. This all shows what kind of person he is, and I don’t think he respects you much. I’m telling you this because I truly want the best for you.

Dounia didn’t answer. She had already made her decision. She was just waiting for the evening.

“Then what is your decision, Rodya?” asked Pulcheria Alexandrovna, who was more worried than ever about his serious tone.

“What decision?”

“Pyotr Petrovitch writes that you can’t be with us tonight, and he will leave if you come. So will you … come?”

“Well, that’s not really up to me. It’s up to you first, if you’re okay with that request; and second, it’s up to Dounia, if she’s okay too. I’ll do what you think is best,” he said dryly.

“Dounia has already decided, and I completely agree with her,” Pulcheria Alexandrovna quickly said.

“I want to ask you, Rodya, to please be with us for this meeting,” Dounia said. “Will you come?”

“Yes.”

“I also want you to be with us at eight o’clock,” she said to Razumihin. “Mother, I’m inviting him too.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Dounia is determined to confront Pyotr Petrovitch and wants Rodya and Razumihin to support her during the meeting.
